title: nymag.com/intelligencer/articl...

last_post.content:
What matters about language in the context of this tech is that language and meaning are relational, that communication is a joint activity, and that systems set up to mimic the form of language can provide the illusion that they understand, that they know things, and that they are reasoning.

So, read this, not that:

https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/ai-artificial-intelligence-chatbots-emily-m-bender.html

title: Catholic group spent millions on app data that tracked gay priests

last_post.content:
Every time one of these articles come out, I remember the time in 2013 that the editor of a major academic journal desk-rejected an article of mine about data leakage from gay dating apps via ad networks, because “gay-focused apps are too niche and non-representative a topic for research to warrant mainstream publication.”

Also, this story is absolutely wild: https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2023/03/09/catholics-gay-priests-grindr-data-bishops/

title: https://bit.ly/ParrotsDay23

last_post.content:
Since we published the #StochasticParrots paper two years ago, the issues discussed in it have only become more urgent and salient. Join me, @timnitGebru @meg Angelina McMillan-Major and an esteemed group of panelists for discussion and reflection, March 17 2023.

https://bit.ly/ParrotsDay23

#AI #ML #AIhype #MathyMath #EthicalAI #AIethics #ethNLP

@rstats

title: Stochastic Parrots Day

last_post.content:
Join us on March 17th for Stochastic Parrots Day marking the 2nd anniversary of the paper. The authors will be joined by scientists, teachers, writers, artists, legal scholars & data workers to discuss the large language model landscape.
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/stochastic-parrots-day-tickets-524219965027

Here's the agenda of the event
with Angelina McMillan-Major, @meg @emilymbender with @timnitGebru @milamiceli @asme @Riedl @safiyanoble @nanjala Steven Zapata, Sarah Andrew, Belzie Mont-Louis and an anonymous data worker.

title: GitHub - rmcelreath/stat_rethinking_2023: Statistical Rethinking Course for Jan-Mar 2023

last_post.content: Statistical Rethinking week 10 has ended, and so has the course for this year. This week demonstrated analyses with allometry, state-based, and population dynamic models, and lots of general advice on planning, doing and reporting research. Memes of the week, explanations in alt text. Course website remains right here: https://github.com/rmcelreath/stat_rethinking_2023

title: Pluralistic: Tiktok’s enshittification (21 Jan 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
To be absolutely clear what I'm saying with my snark about #SiliconValleyBank, I think the venture capital funding inherent in the Silicon Valley startup culture is a very real and increasing problem. It very much contributes to the "enshitification" stage of tech.

And SV/VC tech is taking over everything and turning it to shit.

A big rollback of that model is a very, very good thing IMO.

https://pluralistic.net/2023/01/21/potemkin-ai/#hey-guys

last_post.content:
I agree with @sharplm who wrote on Twitter:

“OpenAI has just released APIs for ChatGPT and Whisper (speech to text). Expect #edtech developers to pile in, with apps for conversational language learning, quizzes, creative (and essay) writing. Add speech for educational toys, virtual worlds, tutoring...”

Some of that will be good, a lot will be bad, but the genie is definitely out of the bottle.

https://openai.com/blog/introducing-chatgpt-and-whisper-apis

title: Better incentives are needed to reward academic software development - Nature Ecology & Evolution

last_post.content:
This article in Nature Ecology & Evolution seems to be making the rounds:

"Better incentives are needed to reward academic software development"
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-023-02008-w

I don't disagree with the premise but one of my hotter takes (I think) is that the solution is not more journal articles but rather recognition of software (and, importantly, its maintenance) as a research output.

title: Multi hash embeddings in spaCy

last_post.content:
Happy to announce the release of spaCy 3.5.1!

It introduces 'spancat_singlelabel', support for mypy v1.0, new operators for the dependency matchers, a 'PlainTextCorpusReader', various bug fixes and more!

We recently also added two new resources:

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets bundles various NER & spancat datasets + .spacy convertors

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/ner_embeddings contains all resources to reproduce the results of our "Multi hash embeddings" technical report: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09255

Happy weekend!

title: https://youtu.be/fYFruezJEDs

last_post.content:
Someone finally did a study based on data from GitHub PRs that measures how it is that teams that do continuous code review (either #pairprogramming or #mobprogramming) are somewhat counterintuitively able to perform so much better than those doing asynchronous code reviews (pull requests). Lotsa queuing theory but it boils down to ensemble programmers having zero interruptions & remaining in a flow state. https://youtu.be/fYFruezJEDs

(Also the psychological safety advantage is huge in my XP ☺️)

title: ITP/IMA Project Fellowship

last_post.content: my department at NYU is now accepting applications for our 2023/2024 Project Fellowship: https://tisch.nyu.edu/itp/itp-ima-project-fellowship basically we'll pay you US$5K to come use our facilities to make a cool project over the course of a semester. pretty good deal if you ask me?

title: Opinion | How ChatGPT Hijacks Democracy

last_post.content:
In 2017, bots submitted over a million comments opposing net neutrality to the FCC. In my view, this man-in-the-middle attack on democracy has been one of the most under-discussed of the past decade.

Somehow last January I missed this piece from Nathan Sanders and Bruce Schneier on how LLMs will turbocharge the threat of similar exploits.

Below, paywall-free link.
https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/15/opinion/ai-chatgpt-lobbying-democracy.html?unlocked_article_code=61TJbKENncOjj4w0qdmX6R_JU9qkQgfcQhqrcslgJBgUWRr34GgvJnhcTuBrCqNMFgMB3tKIJy1TSWLn2gCMbe56i9r9ij9dlwWbiKaF6ht0nlKU2UYd2gNOB1lhcM0yd4nQ8bwRWYVRIPxvaaGqYI9c-KfCyZgPP2u3m3GbMUem-XTDYNKROjD5Aaub68qbX5d9cJRGYeIYpDOXIE6U01rRZXJUCZTOE8_GbD-DelTGJOiJ11HfeSTaHQOylJB2NbdMYr8zNM6U4ToAIN8mralQzFyaB97_UvjykNsVXKxRtT7FsQ1Ele8KKb5UnI6Mkf39axMJaw8n4v4HpEXnRB5i_4fu5oE&smid=url-share

title: WebR Super Simple Demo

last_post.content:
Alrighty then…

Another small #WebR #RStats WASM demo.

This one:

— Loads a package ({jsonlite})
— Yanks `mtcars` from the WebR session
— Converts it to #JSON b/c what WebR returns is garbage for JS datavis libraries — and I don't have time rn to write a function to do the transform.
— Passes it to #VegaLite for the datavis.

It take a couple seconds for vis to show up b/c of WebR initialization & remote pkg loading.

https://rud.is/webr-d3-demo/pkgs.html

title: George Santos masterminded 2017 ATM fraud, former roommate tells feds

last_post.content:
How crazy would it be if George Devolder Santos had an account on the carding forums? Welp, there goes my weekend!

https://www.politico.com/news/2023/03/09/santos-masterminded-atm-fraud-feds-00086417

At the time of his arrest, Trelha had a fake Brazilian ID card and 10 suspected fraudulent cards in his hotel room, according to police documents. An empty FedEx package police found in his rental car was sent from the Winter Park unit he shared with Santos.

Trelha told federal authorities in the declaration Wednesday that his “deal with Santos was 50% for him and 50% for me.”

“We used a computer to be able to download the information on the pieces. We also used an external hard drive to save the filming, because the skimmer took the information from the card, and the camera took the password,” he wrote.

Update: Found the complaint against Ribeiro, Santos' alleged accomplice in the card skimming scheme. It indicates the authorities investigated this as a straight up skimming bust, and didn't look further at whether he was part of a larger conspiracy. No mention of what authorities may have found on the laptop they seized, such as account names or aliases they might have used.

https://krebsonsecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/ribeirocomplaint.pdf

title: https://linuxpuzzles.blinry.org

last_post.content:
This week, I put a fully-functioning Linux in a website, running entirely in client-side Javascript!

🐧 https://linuxpuzzles.blinry.org 🐧

It's a prototype for making web-based command line tutorials. Compared to a game or tool you have to download, I hope they will be much more accessible. ✨

title: StoryWrangler - Twitter Ngram Search

last_post.content:
Elon has announced that the new #Twitter API will cost researchers $42,000 per *month* for access to 0.3% of tweets, so here's your reminder that I built with my colleagues at the VT Complex Systems Center a 10-year, 150 language, data visualization & API of 10% of all public tweets for $250/month API access.

This website has been used to author *countless* #research papers related to mental and physical #health, pandemics, #socialJustice, and #linguistics.

https://storywrangling.org/ngrams

💔

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020 period, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Who’s Behind the NetWire Remote Access Trojan? – Krebs on Security

last_post.content:
New, scoopy: A Croatian national has been arrested for allegedly operating NetWire, a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) marketed on cybercrime forums since 2012 as a stealthy way to spy on infected systems and siphon passwords.

The arrest coincided with a seizure of the NetWire sales website by the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). While the defendant in this case hasn’t yet been named publicly, the NetWire website has been leaking information about the likely true identity and location of its owner for the past 11 years.

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2023/03/whos-behind-the-netwire-remote-access-trojan/

title: HyperCard - Wikipedia

last_post.content:
Apple HyperCard (1987) with Computer Chronicles clip featuring the creator, Bill Atkinson from Apple

Wikipedia -

HyperCard is a software application and development kit for Apple Macintosh and Apple IIGS computers. It is among the first successful hypermedia systems predating the World Wide Web. HyperCard combines a flat-file database with a graphical, flexible, user-modifiable interface.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HyperCard

title: rOpenSci Archive

last_post.content:
With @maelle help, 9 of my #rstats pkgs were just archived on CRAN

- getlandsat
- jaod
- mapr
- pubchunks
- rbace
- rbhl
- rcitoid
- rcoreoa
- rplos

Source code for all can still be found at https://github.com/ropensci-archive + /<package name>

This isn't a bad #opensource outcome - it's a normal outcome when a maintainer moves on (me) and new maintainers can not be found - suggesting the code just isn't useful enough to anyone to take over - BUT! the cran archiving may surface someone(s) that will

title: projects/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets at v3 · explosion/projects

last_post.content:
Happy to announce the release of spaCy 3.5.1!

It introduces 'spancat_singlelabel', support for mypy v1.0, new operators for the dependency matchers, a 'PlainTextCorpusReader', various bug fixes and more!

We recently also added two new resources:

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/span-labeling-datasets bundles various NER & spancat datasets + .spacy convertors

* https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/benchmarks/ner_embeddings contains all resources to reproduce the results of our "Multi hash embeddings" technical report: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09255

Happy weekend!

title: github.com/explosion/projects/...

last_post.content: The sudden collapse of Silicon Valley Bank is sending absolute shockwaves through the tech industry. Nobody is really buying into the narrative that "The risk of contagion is low" - the bottom line is, we don't know. The last 8 years in tech have been really strange, driven by wild monetary policy driving reckless investment decisions even from VC's whom I considered to be fairly conservative. We are due for a wider reckoning. https://www.cnn.com/2023/03/10/investing/svb-bank/index.html
